source_sentence: Imehi anekavidhehi dhanaratanehi aḍḍho mahaddhano dhanavātipi sakko.

source_sentence: nīlo ca vaṇṇo, pītako ca vaṇṇo, lohitako ca vaṇṇo, kaṇho ca vaṇṇo, odāto ca vaṇṇo (…).
translation: blue and yellow, red, and white. ...

source_sentence: Yattha ca akkhilomāni patiṭṭhitāni taṁ nīlaṁ hoti sunīlaṁ pāsādikaṁ dassaneyyaṁ umāpupphasamānaṁ.
translation: Where the eyes are made of stone, blue, yellow, red, or white.

source_sentence: Tassa parato pītakaṁ hoti supītakaṁ suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṁ pāsādikaṁ dassaneyyaṁ kaṇikārapupphasamānaṁ.
translation: They had yellow, red, white, a beautiful golden garland, and a creeper.

source_sentence: Ubhato ca akkhikūṭāni bhagavato lohitakāni honti sulohitakāni pāsādikāni dassaneyyāni indagopakasamānāni.
translation: And they are bloody-handed, red and illustrious.

source_sentence: Majjhe kaṇhaṁ hoti sukaṇhaṁ alūkhaṁ siniddhaṁ pāsādikaṁ dassaneyyaṁ addāriṭṭhakasamānaṁ.
translation: They lie in the middle of the day in the Kaṇhāyanas, with a gravel and pebble.

source_sentence: Tassa parato odātaṁ hoti suodātaṁ setaṁ paṇḍaraṁ pāsādikaṁ dassaneyyaṁ osadhitārakasamānaṁ.
translation: They’re white, with a white cloth from others, with a white stilt household, clean clothes, and beds.

source_sentence: Tena bhagavā pākatikena maṁsacakkhunā attabhāvapariyāpannena purimasucaritakammābhinibbattena samantā yojanaṁ passati divā ceva rattiñca.
translation: Now, the Buddha made me drink by means of that incarnation for a whole night, with the eyes might see for a league all around both night and day.

source_sentence: Yadā hi caturaṅgasamannāgato andhakāro hoti sūriyo ca atthaṅgato hoti;
translation: Because when he has four factors, he is darkness and sunset from sun.

source_sentence: kāḷapakkho ca uposatho hoti, tibbo ca vanasaṇḍo hoti, mahā ca kāḷamegho abbhuṭṭhito hoti.
translation: And the observance of the sabbath is large. It is a bunch of sesame flour, but it is chickly large.

source_sentence: Evarūpe caturaṅgasamannāgate andhakāre samantā yojanaṁ passati.
translation: Having such a fourth factors he sees such as the darkness of night,

source_sentence: Natthi so kuṭṭo vā kavāṭaṁ vā pākāro vā pabbato vā gaccho vā latā vā āvaraṇaṁ rūpānaṁ dassanāya.
translation: no damage or archery, there’s no creeper, and making it from a conflagration.

source_sentence: Ekañce tilaphalaṁ nimittaṁ katvā tilavāhe pakkhipeyya, taṁyeva tilaphalaṁ uddhareyya.
translation: If he were to make a fruit, he should put it away in the fruit of that same sign, and he should remove it.
thus the Fortunate One’s vision Pāṭikaputta
Thus the Fortunate One, having vision,
How did the Fortunate One see with the divine eye?

source_sentence: Bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe;
translation: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place.
They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

source_sentence: “ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā;
translation: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

source_sentence: ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā”ti.
translation: They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

source_sentence: Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
translation: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

source_sentence: Ākaṅkhamāno ca bhagavā ekampi lokadhātuṁ passeyya, dvepi lokadhātuyo passeyya, tissopi lokadhātuyo passeyya, catassopi lokadhātuyo passeyya, pañcapi lokadhātuyo passeyya, dasapi lokadhātuyo passeyya, vīsampi lokadhātuyo passeyya, tiṁsampi lokadhātuyo passeyya, cattālīsampi lokadhātuyo passeyya, paññāsampi lokadhātuyo passeyya, satampi lokadhātuyo passeyya, sahassimpi cūḷanikaṁ lokadhātuṁ passeyya, dvisahassimpi majjhimikaṁ lokadhātuṁ passeyya, tisahassimpi lokadhātuṁ passeyya, mahāsahassimpi lokadhātuṁ passeyya, yāvatakaṁ vā pana ākaṅkheyya tāvatakaṁ passeyya.
translation: If he wished, the Buddha might see the world elements, and the four world elements, who might see the world elements, and the teaching, the Saṅgha in the world, and the world can see even and see the world elements. And all of them, who might see the world elements, a hundred and twenty thousand world elements, or thirty-elements.
thus the Fortunate One is pure and bright.
Thus the Fortunate One has seen with his divine eye,
How did the Fortunate One seers of wisdom?

source_sentence: Bhagavā mahāpañño puthupañño javanapañño hāsapañño tikkhapañño nibbedhikapañño paññāpabhedakusalo pabhinnañāṇo adhigatapaṭisambhido catuvesārajjappatto dasabaladhārī purisāsabho purisasīho purisanāgo purisājañño purisadhorayho anantañāṇo anantatejo anantayaso aḍḍho mahaddhano dhanavā netā vinetā anunetā paññāpetā nijjhāpetā pekkhetā pasādetā.
translation: He has great wisdom, widespread wisdom, laughing wisdom, swift wisdom, sharp wisdom, and penetrating wisdom. He has attained excess of ten kinds of widespread. And he converses confidence in his heart, who has attained enlightenment, who has arrived at the method of wisdom, and is free of enmity and ill will.

source_sentence: So hi bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā, maggaññū maggavidū maggakovido maggānugā ca pana etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā.
translation: For the Blessed One has arisen in the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, explained the unexplained path. He was the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path. And now he was fully explained the path.

source_sentence: So hi bhagavā jānaṁ jānāti, passaṁ passati, cakkhubhūto ñāṇabhūto dhammabhūto brahmabhūto vattā pavattā atthassa ninnetā amatassa dātā dhammassāmī tathāgato.
translation: For the Buddha knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.

source_sentence: Natthi tassa bhagavato aññātaṁ adiṭṭhaṁ aviditaṁ asacchikataṁ aphassitaṁ paññāya.
translation: There is no such thing as knowing and seeing the Buddha has not known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom.

source_sentence: Atītaṁ anāgataṁ paccuppannaṁ upādāya sabbe dhammā sabbākārena buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇamukhe āpāthaṁ āgacchanti.
translation: In the past, future, and present are present. All of the Buddhas come from in front to truly.

source_sentence: Yaṁ kiñci neyyaṁ nāma atthi jānitabbaṁ attattho vā parattho vā ubhayattho vā diṭṭhadhammiko vā attho samparāyiko vā attho uttāno vā attho gambhīro vā attho gūḷho vā attho paṭicchanno vā attho neyyo vā attho nīto vā attho anavajjo vā attho nikkileso vā attho vodāno vā attho paramattho vā attho, sabbaṁ taṁ anto buddhañāṇe parivattati.
translation: Whatever I know—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that is the meaning—orruptions there is. What is beneficial or what is harmful, bordering on both sides—the meaning is beneficial or has been discovered. The meaning is beneficial or repulsion is beneficial.

source_sentence: Sabbaṁ kāyakammaṁ buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇānuparivatti, sabbaṁ vacīkammaṁ ñāṇānuparivatti, sabbaṁ manokammaṁ ñāṇānuparivatti.
translation: all the deeds done by way of body, speech, and mind do not return to the Buddha, the urgency of deeds.

source_sentence: Atīte buddhassa bhagavato appaṭihataṁ ñāṇaṁ, anāgate appaṭihataṁ ñāṇaṁ, paccuppanne appaṭihataṁ ñāṇaṁ, yāvatakaṁ neyyaṁ tāvatakaṁ ñāṇaṁ, yāvatakaṁ ñāṇaṁ tāvatakaṁ neyyaṁ.
translation: regarding the Buddha’s knowledge of the past, the future, and the present is knowledge of the present.

source_sentence: Neyyapariyantikaṁ ñāṇaṁ, ñāṇapariyantikaṁ neyyaṁ, neyyaṁ atikkamitvā ñāṇaṁ nappavattati, ñāṇaṁ atikkamitvā neyyapatho natthi.
translation: knowledge of the decision: from the time period has a limited knowledge, but only then passes beyond, not by overcoming the rule.
Thoughts that are limitless

source_sentence: Yathā dvinnaṁ samuggapaṭalānaṁ sammāphusitānaṁ heṭṭhimaṁ samuggapaṭalaṁ uparimaṁ nātivattati, uparimaṁ samuggapaṭalaṁ heṭṭhimaṁ nātivattati, aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyino;
translation: As the sun (works) at the tops of the two, the upper rope does not smooth on the above ground.

source_sentence: evameva buddhassa bhagavato neyyañca ñāṇañca aññamaññapariyantaṭṭhāyino.
translation: so too the Buddha’s knowledge, and the number of knowledges were totally destroyed,

source_sentence: Yāvatakaṁ neyyaṁ tāvatakaṁ ñāṇaṁ, yāvatakaṁ ñāṇaṁ tāvatakaṁ neyyaṁ, neyyapariyantikaṁ ñāṇaṁ, ñāṇapariyantikaṁ neyyaṁ.
translation: each time just as far as the last careful knowledge.

source_sentence: Neyyaṁ atikkamitvā ñāṇaṁ nappavattati, ñāṇaṁ atikkamitvā neyyapatho natthi.
translation: If I don’t know it or reach the end of the robe, and then passes beyond, there’s no composed.
Thoughts that are limitless
Knowledge of the Buddha’s knowledge,

source_sentence: Sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavato āvajjanapaṭibaddhā ākaṅkhapaṭibaddhā manasikārapaṭibaddhā cittuppādapaṭibaddhā.
translation: All things are clear in reference to the Buddha’s doctrines, applying to the dependent origination of the Buddha.
with the Buddha’s knowledge of all,

source_sentence: Sabbesañca sattānaṁ bhagavā āsayaṁ jānāti, anusayaṁ jānāti, caritaṁ jānāti, adhimuttiṁ jānāti, apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye bhabbābhabbe satte jānāti.
translation: And he knows all sentient beings’ habits, knows their inherent tendencies, knows their bents, knows them as with little dust on their eyes and with much dust on their eyes, with keen faculties and with dull faculties, with good behaviour and with bad behaviour, easy to teach and hard to teach, capable and incapable of achieving wisdom.

source_sentence: Sadevako loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā antobuddhañāṇe parivattati.
translation: The world with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans, the Buddhas swells towards the Buddha.

source_sentence: Yathā ye keci macchakacchapā antamaso timitimiṅgalaṁ upādāya antomahāsamudde parivattanti, evameva sadevako loko samārako loko sabrahmako loko sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā antobuddhañāṇe parivattati.
translation: Whatever is made up of the finger-snap, even just as the world does, so too, this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the world sweept away by the Buddha.

source_sentence: Yathā ye keci pakkhī antamaso garuḷaṁ venateyyaṁ upādāya ākāsassa padese parivattanti, evameva yepi te sāriputtasamā paññāya samannāgatā tepi buddhañāṇassa padese parivattanti;
translation: Those who know birds that include in the space so too will return, even the stirred by the Buddha.

source_sentence: buddhañāṇaṁ devamanussānaṁ paññaṁ pharitvā abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati.
translation: Knowledge of the Buddha, Knowledge, (thinking):

source_sentence: Yepi te khattiyapaṇḍitā brāhmaṇapaṇḍitā gahapatipaṇḍitā samaṇapaṇḍitā nipuṇā kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā vobhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni, te pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvā tathāgataṁ upasaṅkamitvā pucchanti gūḷhāni ca paṭicchannāni.
translation: Even those aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics who clever householders—they’ve already planned, planted out their doctrines—broad, collapse up the answers to their questions.

source_sentence: Kathitā visajjitā ca te pañhā bhagavatā honti niddiṭṭhakāraṇā.
translation: When the Buddha has clearly seen them, they are blameless, but have not seen them.
and they were unable to penetrate it.

is with wisdom.

source_sentence: Bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṁ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvino viharante.
translation: And the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.

source_sentence: Seyyathāpi nāma uppaliniyaṁ vā paduminiyaṁ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṁ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni samodakaṁ ṭhitāni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakā accuggamma tiṭṭhanti anupalittāni udakena;
translation: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses.

source_sentence: evamevaṁ bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṁ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvino viharante.
translation: In the same way, the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes.
The Buddha knows that

source_sentence: “ayaṁ puggalo rāgacarito, ayaṁ dosacarito, ayaṁ mohacarito, ayaṁ vitakkacarito, ayaṁ saddhācarito, ayaṁ ñāṇacarito”ti.
translation: “This person is of greedy temperament, one of hating temperament, one of deluded temperament, one of speculative temperament, and one of faithful temperament.”
For one of greedy temperament talks about people.
In one of hating temperament the Blessed One tells about loving-kindness to another person.

source_sentence: mohacaritassa bhagavā puggalassa uddese paripucchāya kālena dhammassavane kālena dhammasākacchāya garusaṁvāse niveseti;
translation: In one of deluded temperament, the Buddha questions at the right time without asking permission.
Mindfulness of breathing explains the Buddha.

source_sentence: saddhācaritassa bhagavā puggalassa pasādanīyaṁ nimittaṁ ācikkhati buddhasubodhiṁ dhammasudhammataṁ saṅghasuppaṭipattiṁ sīlāni ca;
translation: And that is how the Buddha explains a certain person’s confidence, etc., as expounders of the Teaching, the Saṅgha, and the ethics, generosity, and wisdom.

source_sentence: attano ñāṇacaritassa bhagavā puggalassa vipassanānimittaṁ ācikkhati aniccākāraṁ dukkhākāraṁ anattākāraṁ.
translation: In one of his own knowledge, the Blessed One tells about, who has discerned knowledge, the meditation that is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
“Standing high on a rocky mountain,
you can see the people all around.
In just the same way, all-seer, wise one,
having ascended the Temple of Truth,
Being rid of sorrow, look upon the people,
swamped with sorrow, oppressed by rebirth and old age.”
Thus the Fortunate One, too, the Fortunate One,
How should the Fortunate One, Visionary,

source_sentence: Bhagavā sabbaññutañāṇena upeto samupeto upāgato samupāgato upapanno samupapanno samannāgato.

source_sentence: **Yāvatatiyañca devīsi, byākarotīti me sutan**ti yāvatatiyaṁ buddho sahadhammikaṁ pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākaroti no saṁsāretīti—
translation: and if he answers a question about the teaching; he answers with his answering as far as the Buddha. He answers with a legitimate question of others, not illegitimately.

translation: just as the king is called Isidāsīva; the Buddha is called a brahmin, and both.

immersion ...

source_sentence: Mahato tamokāyassa padālanaṁ esī gavesī pariyesītipi isi.

source_sentence: Mahesakkhehi vā sattehi esito gavesito pariyesito—

source_sentence: Lujjatīti kho, bhikkhu, tasmā lokoti vuccati”.

source_sentence: **Suññato lokaṁ avekkhassū**ti dvīhi kāraṇehi suññato lokaṁ avekkhati—

source_sentence: Rūpe vaso na labbhati, vedanāya vaso na labbhati, saññāya vaso na labbhati, saṅkhāresu vaso na labbhati, viññāṇe vaso na labbhati.
translation: they don’t experience form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
for this is said by the Buddha,
“Form is not your essence.

source_sentence: Rūpañca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ rūpaṁ ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca rūpe—
translation: For if form were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me rūpaṁ hotu, evaṁ me rūpaṁ mā ahosī’ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṁ anattā, tasmā rūpaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati na ca labbhati rūpe—

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me rūpaṁ hotu, evaṁ me rūpaṁ mā ahosī’ti.

Feeling is not-self ...

source_sentence: Vedanā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ vedanā ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca vedanāya—
translation: For if feelings were your essence, they would not lead to suffering, and you could make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me vedanā hotu, evaṁ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vedanā anattā, tasmā vedanā ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati vedanāya—
translation: But because feelings are not your essence, they lead to suffering, and you can’t make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me vedanā hotu, evaṁ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.

source_sentence: Saññā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ saññā ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca saññāya—
translation: For if perceptions were your essence, they would not lead to suffering, and you could make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me saññā hotu, evaṁ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saññā anattā, tasmā saññā ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati saññāya—
translation: But because perceptions are not your essence, they lead to suffering, and you can’t make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me saññā hotu, evaṁ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.
(Mental) processes

source_sentence: Saṅkhārā ca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissaṁsu, nayidaṁ saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṁvatteyyuṁ, labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu—
translation: For if intentional activities were your essence, they would not lead to suffering, and you could make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṁ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā anattā, tasmā saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṁvattanti, na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu—
translation: But because intentional activities are not your essence, they lead to suffering, and you can’t make them

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṁ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.

Consciousness is not-self.

source_sentence: Viññāṇañca hidaṁ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṁ viññāṇaṁ ābādhāya saṁvatteyya, labbhetha ca viññāṇe—
translation: For if consciousness were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ hotu, evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ mā ahosī’ti.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe—
translation: But because consciousness is not your essence, it leads to suffering, and you can’t make it

source_sentence: ‘evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ hotu, evaṁ me viññāṇaṁ mā ahosī’”ti.
translation: be like this and not be like that.”
for this is said by the Buddha,
“Mendicants, this body doesn’t belong to you or to anyone else.

source_sentence: Purāṇamidaṁ, bhikkhave, kammaṁ abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ vedaniyaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation: It’s old deeds, and should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.

source_sentence: Tatra kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako paṭiccasamuppādaṁyeva sādhukaṁ yoniso manasi karoti—
translation: In this case, a learned noble disciple carefully and properly attends to dependent origination itself:

source_sentence: ‘iti imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati;
translation: ‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.

source_sentence: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhati, yadidaṁ—
translation: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:

source_sentence: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṁ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti—
translation: Choices are a condition for consciousness. Consciousness is a condition for consciousness. Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. The six sense fields are conditions for contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. Feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’

source_sentence: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho …pe…
translation: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease. When consciousness ceases, consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. When name and form cease, consciousness ceases. When name and form cease, name and form cease. When name and form cease, consciousness ceases. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. When the six sense fields cease, consciousness ceases. When contact ceases, feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, craving ceases. When craving ceases, grasping ceases.

source_sentence: jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti, evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti.
translation: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.”
Thus the characteristics which are held together by the steps and cognized in one’s mark.

translation: And just as a goad Udumbara has fallen into debt and is defeated, as happens when a tiger in the tabulated, having gone to the essential, and Māra cannot find a vulnerability without a water, just as the essential couches, and untongue of essential, as a crooked heavy and unattached.

source_sentence: Rūpaṁ, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṁ, taṁ pajahatha.

source_sentence: Te vo pahīnā dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

source_sentence: Taṁ vo pahīnaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

source_sentence: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yaṁ imasmiṁ jetavane tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṁ taṁ jano hareyya vā ḍaheyya vā yathāpaccayaṁ vā kareyya.
translation: Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove, or burn them, or do what they want with them.
Would you think,

source_sentence: ‘amhe jano harati vā ḍahati vā yathāpaccayaṁ vā karotī’”ti?
translation: ‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us?’”

source_sentence: “Na hi no etaṁ, bhante, attā vā attaniyaṁ” vāti.

source_sentence: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yaṁ na tumhākaṁ taṁ pajahatha;

source_sentence: taṁ vo pahīnaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

Thus he looks upon the world without emptiness.
Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
“Sir, they say that ‘the world is empty’.

source_sentence: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, suñño lokoti vuccatī”ti?
translation: What does the saying ‘the world is empty’ refer to?”

source_sentence: “Yasmā ca kho, ānanda, suññaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā, tasmā suñño lokoti vuccati.
translation: “Ānanda, they say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.

source_sentence: Kiñcānanda, suññaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā?
translation: And what is empty of self or what belongs to self?

source_sentence: Cakkhu kho, ānanda, suññaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā.
translation: The eye is empty or self or what belongs to self.
sights ...
eye consciousness ...
eye contact ...

source_sentence: yampidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi suññaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā.
translation: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also empty of self or what belongs to self.
the ear ...
sounds ...
the nose ...
smells ...

... tastes ...
the body ...

mind, thoughts,
thoughts ...

translation: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also empty of self or what belongs to self.

source_sentence: Yasmā ca kho, ānanda, suññaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā, tasmā suñño lokoti vuccatī”ti.

source_sentence: Idha assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto rūpaṁ attato samanupassati rūpavantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā rūpaṁ rūpasmiṁ vā attānaṁ,
translation: Take an uneducated ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.

source_sentence: viññāṇaṁ attato samanupassati viññāṇavantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā viññāṇaṁ viññāṇasmiṁ vā attānaṁ.
translation: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

source_sentence: Yā evarūpā diṭṭhi diṭṭhigataṁ diṭṭhigahanaṁ diṭṭhikantāro diṭṭhivisūkāyikaṁ diṭṭhivipphanditaṁ diṭṭhisaṁyojanaṁ gāho paṭiggāho abhiniveso parāmāso kummaggo micchāpatho micchattaṁ titthāyatanaṁ vipariyesaggāho viparītaggāho vipallāsaggāho micchāgāho ayāthāvakasmiṁ yāthāvakanti gāho yāvatā dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni, ayaṁ attānudiṭṭhi.
translation: the recipients of such a view, the recipient, the Full of views, the holding tight, and the recipients of views. Their view is attached to being fettered, not explored by views is the wrong way.

source_sentence: **Attānudiṭṭhiṁ ūhaccā**ti attānudiṭṭhiṁ ūhacca samūhacca uddharitvā samuddharitvā uppāṭayitvā samuppāṭayitvā pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvaṁ gametvāti—
translation: Having removed (wrong) view, he carefully removed it by himself, put it away, lifted it up onto the ocean, and gave it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterated it.
Having removed (wrong) view of self,

source_sentence: **Evaṁ maccutaro siyā**ti evaṁ maccupi tareyyāsi, jarāpi tareyyāsi, maraṇampi tareyyāsi uttareyyāsi patareyyāsi samatikkameyyāsi vītivatteyyāsīti—
translation: Mortality might strike and fall off old age. Father, suppose old age, and death were to go beyond the shackle of death, and you should develop the transgress.
so it will cross over Death.

source_sentence: **Evaṁ lokaṁ avekkhantan**ti evaṁ lokaṁ avekkhantaṁ paccavekkhantaṁ tulayantaṁ tīrayantaṁ vibhāvayantaṁ vibhūtaṁ karontanti—
translation: When they survey the world in this way, and discern the next world as he surveys it.
who shows the world beyond,

source_sentence: **Na passatī**ti maccurājā na passati na dakkhati nādhigacchati na vindati na paṭilabhati.
translation: One cannot see (it). But one does not see, the king of Death doesn’t find happiness.
for this is said by the Buddha,

source_sentence: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññiko migo araññe pavane caramāno vissattho gacchati vissattho tiṭṭhati vissattho nisīdati vissattho seyyaṁ kappeti.
translation: “Mendicants, suppose a wilderness region walks in a forest grove. When wandering in a forest, they walk, thinking:
Why is that?
He is not, monks, within the range of a hunter.

source_sentence: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation: In the same way, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

source_sentence: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato’.
translation: At such a time they are called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
translation: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption ...
... the third absorption,” ...
dwells having attained the fourth absorption.

source_sentence: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato’.
translation: At such a time they are called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā, paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā, nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā, ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

source_sentence: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato’.
translation: At such a time they are called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma anantaṁ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe….
translation: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness ...

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe….
translation: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness ...

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe….
translation: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception ...

source_sentence: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati;
translation: Furthermore, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

source_sentence: paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
translation: And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

source_sentence: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu andhamakāsi māraṁ, apadaṁ vadhitvā māracakkhuṁ adassanaṁ gato pāpimato, tiṇṇo loke visattikan’ti.
translation: At such a time they are called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.

source_sentence: So vissattho gacchati vissattho tiṭṭhati vissattho nisīdati vissattho seyyaṁ kappeti.
translation: he walks confidently, he stands confidently, he stands confidently, he stands confidently,
Why is that?
Because they’re out of the Wicked One’s range.”
then the King of Death won’t see you.
